identificationModule.briefTitle: Effect of Partially Hydrolyzed Formula With Synbiotics on Skin Barrier Function
identificationModule.officialTitle: Synbiotics in Partially Hydrolysed Formula for Improved skiN Barrier Function in Infants at Risk for Allergy (SPHINX Study)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The main purpose of this study is to assess the efficacy of a partially hydrolyzed formula with synbiotics in halting one of the first steps of the allergic march (atopic dermatitis) in infants at risk of allergy. Other efficacy and safety parameters will be assessed as well.

primaryOutcomes.description: TransEpidermal water loss will be measured using a validated non-invasive technique.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Cumulative incidence of AD is based on physician diagnosis using the United Kingdom Working Party (UKWP) diagnosis criteria.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Epidermal water loss will be measured using a validated non-invasive technique.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Skin hydration will be measured with a corneometer device.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Extent and severity of Atopic Dermatitis
secondaryOutcomes.description: SCORAD (SCORing for Atopic Dermatitis), scores range from 0 to 103, with higher scores indicating higher atopic dermatitis severity
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From 3 months to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Cumulative use of topical steroids and calcineurin inhibitors
secondaryOutcomes.description: Use of medication to treat AD and other symptoms will be collected via parent self-reported questionnaire.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Concentration of skin cytokines such as IL4 and IL5 using immunoassays
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Concentration of skin natural moisturizing factors such as Pyrrolidone carboxylic acid, using HPLC
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Concentration of skin stratum corneum lipids such as ceramides, cholesterol and triacylglycerol using mass spectrometry
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Overall skin microbiome composition and diversity using next-generation sequencing
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Levels of skin metabolites using targeted or untargeted approaches.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Levels of plasma proteins using mass cytometry or immunoassaysand immunoassays.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 6 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Levels of immune cell populations using mass cytometry or immunoassays
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 6 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Specific IgE antibodies will be measured using Phadiatop infant®.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Overall fecal microbiota composition, diversity, different bacteria taxa and microbiota community types assessed using next generation sequencing (NGS) technology
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Levels of fecal metabolites using targeted or untargeted approaches.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Fecal biomarkers of inflammation and immunity
secondaryOutcomes.description: Levels of fecal markers of immune health and inflammation such as total secretory IgA (sIgA), calprotectin, and α-1-antitrypsin assessed by ELISA.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Number of participants with Physician-diagnosed allergic manifestations.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Infant Gastrointestinal Symptom Questionnaire (IGSQ), scores range from 13 to 65, with higher scores indicating higher gastrointestinal discomfort.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At enrollment and 4 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Weight (g and z-scores)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Length (cm and z-scores)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Head circumference (cm and z-scores)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 12 months of age

secondaryOutcomes.description: Incidence of adverse events
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment to 13 months of age

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

1. Written informed consent has been obtained from at least one parent or legally acceptable representative (LAR), if applicable
2. Infant gestational age ≥ 37 completed weeks
3. Infant birth weight of ≥ 2.5 kg and ≤ 4.5 kg
4. Infant postnatal age ≤ 14 days (date of birth = day 0) at enrollment
5. Infant from singleton birth or infant from multiple births may if all birth siblings are enrolled.
6. At least one biological parent or sibling has (or had) a medically diagnosed history of allergy, based on response to a simple screening questionnaire
7. a. For the breastfed reference group only: infant is exclusively breastfed since birth with no intake of formula, and their parent(s) have the intention to continue exclusive breastfeeding until at least 4 months of age.

   or b. For the randomized formula-fed groups only: infant is exclusively or predominantly formula-fed in the 24 hours prior to enrollment, with formula feeding representing at least 75% of total daily feeds. The decision to introduce formula feeding was independently made by the parents before enrollment.
8. Parents/LAR must be able to provide evidence of parental authority and identity.
9. Infant's parent(s)/LAR must understand the informed consent form and other study documents and are willing and able to fulfill the requirements of the study protocol.

Exclusion Criteria:

1. Infectious, metabolic, congenital, genetic, gastrointestinal illness or any other condition (e.g., gastrointestinal surgery) that could impact oral feeding, growth or study outcomes.
2. Infants with special dietary needs other than standard infant formula (e.g., extensively hydrolyzed formula, amino acid formula, special formula for metabolic diseases) or requiring tube feeding.
3. Infant has already been diagnosed with allergy by a physician, including AD and/or cow's milk allergy.
4. Infant is currently participating or has previously participated in another clinical trial prior to enrollment.
5. Infant's parents or LARs have not reached legal age of majority (18 years).
